text: Oscar, great to have you on the show again. How are you? I'm very good, thank you.
Yeah, I'm good. I'm good. Please to be back at it again. Yes.
Yeah, nice to be back. A long winter. And thank you for allowing us what I call backstage.
We're in this drive, is room. What goes on in here? Anything and everything.
Naps, warming up, chilling out, crying if you need to. Everything that happens is in here.
I've always wondered, you know when you go to the grid and then there's quite a long period now
before the race starts. Do you come back to your drivers room during that time? No.
We go back to the garage and talk to some engineers but they've made it shorter again.
This year now. So there's actually not that much time. So there's probably not going to be me sitting on TV
watching a jetpack full of the sky again. But no, I don't come back here in between.
Do you have any pre-race rituals that take place in here? I'm thinking, you know, I'm reminded of
Keith Richards from the Rolling Stones. Before he goes on stage, he likes to eat a shepherd's pie.
Does Oscar Piaestry have any slightly weird pre-race rituals like that? No, no, no, I don't.
I mean I do a warm up before each race that's the same thing. There's some small tweaks here
and there depending on what hurts that day. But that's the only thing. Yeah, there's no shepherd's
pies. There's nothing special. There's jumping. You just jump in and do it.
Jump in and do it exactly. Well, the last time I saw you before Bahrain
was the FIA prize giving in Baku where you were picking up your rookie of the year award.
So clearly it went really well for a rookie. But just how do you reflect on your first year in
Formula One? I think it was good, yeah. I mean, I would say there was quite a few weekends
where I thought I could have done a better job. There was definitely some weekends where I left it
saying, you know, I'm proud of that. And quite a few weekends in the middle where I went, well,
I did some things good, some things I can do a bit better. So on the whole, I was pretty happy
with it, I would say getting a rookie trophy at the end of it was nice. But I mean, that's not really
why I'm in Formula One to be honest. But yeah, I think it was a good year. I think, you know, now that
I've come back for the second year, I kind of realised just how draining a Formula One season is
and how much energy, you know, sort of a management you need to do for yourself. And, you know,
taking care of yourself from that side. So I think already that's paying dividends, I hope.
But no, I thought it was a good first year in F1, but certainly a long way from the ceiling of what
I can do. I hope. It does lead me to ask. You know, you say there were some things where you felt
you could have done a bit better. What kind of areas are we talking about? I think in general,
there was probably two standout things. I think the consistency or lack of that I had last year was
not exactly how I wanted it to be. I think I was quite up and down in a few weekends.
You're talking weekend to weekend to weekend. Yeah, weekend to weekend.
And so I think just having more consistency across the year would be, it's always a positive thing.
But I think that was something that I wasn't particularly happy with. And then managing the tyres
in a race that was from a, you know, specifically driving point of view. That was probably the biggest
focus that I took into this year and biggest thing I wanted to improve. I think my quality pace
in especially the second half of last year was there or thereabouts most of the time, but the race
pace was a bit more hit and miss. So that was something I really focused on. I think in Bahrain,
it was a good step in the right direction. On what is a pretty high-dead circuit,
you know, it felt like my entire management was decent. So that was a big focus for me and hopefully,
well, give myself a few more races to see if I've really kind of turned it around. But I think it's
been a good start on that from. Do you know, all this raises the question of just how hard it is
for rookies to come into Formula One? And is it a coincidence that 2024 is the first year in history
that we have no rookies? Because teams aren't willing to risk.
Well, I mean, yes and no. It's, I mean, it is very tough. I think for me, like coming to F1,
you know, it's the first time I've raced against people that are so experienced in life, but in
anything, you know, I think in all my junior racing, I did, I think the most experienced somebody had
was three years in the same category. And you know, in my first season, Lando, who is not exactly
old, you know, he already had five. So or four, going into his fifth. So, you know, that's that kind
of experience, especially in the world of F1 really, I think goes a long way. And I feel like already,
you know, I'm learning that. And I think everybody is at such a high level that, you know, if you don't
get things a bit, if you get things a bit wrong, you know, everyone will pounce on you. And especially
the people that have the that experience, it's, you know, they just have more experience of good
and bad. And you know, I think for me, with the limited testing that we have, you kind of have
to learn things on the fly, which means having a few bad races here and there, which I definitely had.
So that part is very hard. And I think trusting a rookie is not that easy.
Yeah, I think, you know, McLaren took definitely, I want to, I want to hope a calculated risk
on bringing me into the team. But yeah, there's always kind of that uncertainty on, you know, first,
I guess, firstly, whether you're going to survive in the world of F1, it's certainly not easy.
And then whether you're, you know, going to be capable and, you know, have that sort of
room to develop over time as well. So I think it's, it is very tough. I feel like
more rookies maybe should be given a chance. I think it'll be interesting to see what happens
to the 2025 grid. There could be a few new faces. But yeah, Oscar, I feel you were particularly
raw coming in last year because you've obviously, you weren't racing a year before. You didn't do any
Friday practices. Yeah, you know, actually in hindsight, when did you feel fully up to speed?
A week ago, Embarrassing. Are we talking mid season?
I mean, I think even towards the end of the season, I think there was, there was kind of two factors
at play. I think probably about mid season, I started to feel more comfortable and more confident.
I think once you get a few results on the board or even if it's not results, you know,
I mean, your teammate is your best comparison. So I think if you get, you know, a few decent results
against your teammate on the board or, you know, you get close even, it boosts your confidence a bit.
And then your mid season, those are a few good results, I think. Was that the catalyst for you,
you feeling comfortable? Was the good results or was it one change technically to the car or
a change in approach? Not really. I mean, I always try to remove results from, you know, my mindset
and my thinking, but I think especially when you've not had any and when you're so new,
you come, you sometimes need that, that result. And, you know, I think for me, even in my junior
racing, you know, sometimes even in testing, it was like a lap in testing that I went, I drove well,
the car was good. That's where I need the car to feel like every time. Just those kind of things
to anchor yourself on are very important. And I think Silverstone last year was definitely the first
kind of place where I felt that genuinely. I think even here in Saudi, I qualified in the top 10
for the first time. And that was at the time a very big result for us and for me personally. So,
I gained quite a lot of confidence from that result. Even just getting my first points on the
board in Melbourne, even if I was quite lucky, you know, getting the points on the board was a nice box
to tick. So I think it really started to come together more mid season, especially after Silverstone,
like I said, close to a podium. I felt like that was one of my strongest weekends of the year, but
that's where it took a bit of a turn for the better. But then the second half of the year, we had
so many new circuits that I think we had like seven new tracks in a row or something that I'd never
been to. So what I'd gained in sort of comfort and experience with the car, I then lost again with
experience of the tracks in the second half of the year. And there was a few sprint weekends thrown
in there and that made life tricky as well. So it's a mixed sprints. Some sprints, yeah. The first few
sprints were what it's fine to me. Spire was great, guitar obviously was very good, but Austin and
Brazil struggled a lot. So having that lack of experience or lack of practice time definitely
ate away and it wasn't a linear progression. There was some weekends in the middle of the year that
I thought very strong. Some weekends towards the very end of the year that some of my worst I would say.
So it was kind of up and down through the whole year and part of that was probably being tired,
being it sounds very boring, but you know just getting to the end of the season or those
flyaway races, you know that's the first time in my life I've done that much traveling and
experiencing it firsthand. So how do you make that easier? I mean I think even just experiencing it
the first time, you know when you've not lived it before you don't know what you're getting yourself
into. So I think even now having just experienced that and knowing what to expect again,
you know it puts your mind a little bit at ease of you know you survived through it obviously, but
that's the first thing and then you obviously try and work with the team, with your trainer,
whoever it is, all of the above to make things as easy for you as possible. Are you going to change
your travel plans this year or is it just an acceptance that when you first land in Vegas you're
going to feel rubbish and let the adrenaline take over? I mean there's always that sort of things
that you can't get around you. Jet lag, you can try as hard as you like and there are certain
things you can do to help, but you're never going to fully fix it especially when you go to Vegas and
you don't see sunlight for three days that really doesn't help. So you know those little things will
get looked at definitely and scrutinized, you know my sort of scheduling, commitments, all of those
kind of things by my training leading up around those events, you know trying to fit that in in such
a busy schedule is not easy but necessary. So just all of those little things you kind of need to
keep on top of which you know maybe you've got a bit overwhelming points. What are the
aspects of the Oscar necessary to take a break? Yes as well. And did you down tools over the winter and
nothing about Formula One for a few weeks? Yes. Yeah I went home to Melbourne for three weeks
which was nice. Saw my family, saw my friends. I have to say the winter break felt like it was very
short. It came around, by-rain came around quick and I know I'm not the first person to say that either.
It was long enough to get a bit of a break in and just take some time to reflect as well.
You know it would be, last year was so different to the two years I had before that.
You know the F2 season I did, we had eight race weekends versus 22 last year in the weekend,
the 2022, I didn't have any race weekends. So that was definitely a very different experience
in terms of all the travelling especially all the flyaways. Yeah that was a very new experience.
And when you were hooking up with all your old mates back in Melbourne over the winter,
did it dawn on you just how different your life age 22 is compared to their life?
Age 22, 23 whatever they are. Definitely yeah. It's kind of weird every time I go back home and
see them and my sisters for that matter and pretty much everyone in my life in Australia. It's
always, sometimes it can be a bit shocking how different things are. Some of my friends there,
I'm used to spending time with them after school or in school holidays and now they're actually
working and they've got jobs. Real jobs. Even just scheduling that in as well it's kind of like
oh can you catch up like today or tomorrow? I was like oh I've got work and I'm like oh yeah
I forgot that that exists. So yeah it's nice to go back and see them but yeah it is,
there is some logistical challenges with trying to see people when you don't work a 9-5 job but
no it's always nice to go back and spend that time with them and yeah you know just spend time
with old friends and not think about F1.
If you listen to our episode with Sergio Perez at the start of the season you'll know that I've
been waiting for a package to arrive on my doorstep and guess what was waiting for me when I got back
from the Saudi Grand Prix. That's right it was my Indochino delivery. Indochino makes fully
customised suits that don't require a trip to the tailor to get that perfect fit. With Indochino
you've got the option to measure yourself at home or visit a showroom where they'll do it for you

and I used Indochino online to set up my personalised measurements profile for one of their
Haley cotton stretch shirts and I've already opened the shirt and tried it on and of course it fits
perfectly and it will make its first race weekend appearance in Melbourne this coming weekend.
I'll be the guy in the perfectly tailored blue shirt. The website is so incredibly thorough when
you're placing an order. It walks you through every single measurement you'll need which only takes
about 10 minutes in total and when it comes to customisation they've thought about everything
from the length to the buttons the collar and the pockets and I loved that you even had the
option to select what style cuff you wanted to go for. It's these little details that make
all the difference so level up your game with Indochino go to Indochino.com and use the code
grid to get 10% off any purchase of $399 or more. That's 10% off at iandochion.com with the code grid.
I did just want to ask you about the sprint in kato of course you won the race and one of the things
apart from your speed obviously that really stood out for me last year was your coolness,
ice cool, sort of rick and an s I feel. I want to ask you what it was like you're leading that race.
Max Verstappen is bearing down on you. What were you thinking at that moment?
A few things. I think the first thing was I knew there wasn't that long left in the sprint. I think
it was like five laps left or six laps left and the gap was like I want to say two seconds or
two and a half seconds so I knew it was going to be pretty tight because I mean yeah I don't need to
say more do I. So at that point I was kind of like you know how quickly is he going to catch me
and like how hard am I going to have to fight. But then after like the first lap he got into second
and then the second lap he didn't take that much out of me. I think even the second lap we were
pretty much even. So from that point on once I was actually quite confident that we could that we
could win and then from that point I was a very long like two or three laps trying to get to the
end but yeah I was honestly quite relaxed but those first couple of laps it was yeah quite the
opposite. Just know you know I've been in that position fortunately a couple of times in my career
already and it's yeah an interesting feeling when you've got a quicker car behind you but
yeah that time we had enough to hang on which was cool. You know we've referenced race management
already and is there anything you can do explain for us mere mortals who have never driven a
Formula One car is there anything you can do to prepare your arsenal for the attack from someone
like Maxper Stappen in terms of looking after your tyres. Were you driving differently before he
got up behind you? Is there anything you can do with all the systems in the car that
to a very limited extent? Yes. You can do some things you can look after the tyres a little bit
you know you can charge the battery up if you want but both of those things come at a cost of lap
time right so if you want to charge the battery up fully for when he gets to you he's going to get
to you even quicker. If you want to look after the tyres for when he gets to you he's going to catch
you even quicker. So there's almost an element of do I push flat out and just try and hang on
which is kind of what I did or do you you know kind of just wait for the attack to come but
I think you know when you've got a quicker car behind you like that especially the Red Bull that
has a very powerful D.R.S. and top end speed there's not that much you can do to stop it. It's
almost you know prevention is the best you know the best way to attack it rather than waiting for it
to happen and trying to fight it so that was kind of the the mentality I had and
yeah fortunately it worked and how did it feel? How do you reflect on that win? It's not going to
go down in history as a Grand Prix win. Unfortunately I don't know but how important was it?
I think at the time I didn't really appreciate it that much. Really? Yeah honestly
we had a race the next like we had the Grand Prix the next day
I think I was actually more excited to qualify and pole than crossing the line first for the sprint
because you know the sprint shootout was basically the same as qualifying just had a different name.
So you know when you beat everyone else you know on merit you know I feel like there's
in some racing situations even the sprint to some extent you know a few guys got through on
softs and you know Max got put back in the pack a little bit and you know a few things went my way
a little bit I still did my job of getting back to the front but there's those kind of variables
in qualifying it's you the track and whoever's the quickest that's who wins right?
So I was very happy about that part of the weekend the sprint I was certainly happy with
but I then knew I had the Grand Prix the next day so I don't think it was till after that weekend
and like probably even into the offseason where I went okay that's it's pretty cool like I was one
of two guys or three guys to beat Max for the whole year one of the two non-red ball winners even if
it wasn't a a Grand Prix so in hindsight a very very cool achievement and you know something I'm
very proud of but at the moment honestly you know even asking my engineers I think they're expecting
a bit more probably so yeah it didn't sink in immediately. And Max Damott did steal the headlines
that night didn't he? Yeah he couldn't have waited the next day to win the World Championship like
I think Lando actually said it stole my thunder a little bit but I was okay with that I was happy
with with the win anyway. Look what about Lando you know you you you seem to rub along at least
from the outside very well together is that is that the reality? Yeah I would say so we we
certainly work well together you know I think we're always pushing each other to be quicker and quicker
you know which is what you want as teammates and is it a completely open door policy here at McLean?
Yeah everything on his car you can see and you can see on your car and yeah I mean sometimes we
ask each other questions about how we're driving or what we felt and stuff like that. Oh come on
is it tempting? To what? To say something that's not true. No of course. Probably is the data
doesn't it? Yeah exactly the data doesn't lie so it's yeah I mean we share you know everything from
that side of things so I think we work together really well and I think last year
you know certainly not going to take credit for the turnaround that we had but I like to think that
the way that me and Lando work together you know helped boost everyone in the team a bit
and we've always had very similar feedback on what we want from the car so I think from an
engineering point of view that makes life a bit simpler for the engineers especially if they're
at a bit of a crossroads of you know two different parts it's nice to have the same or roughly the
same feedback so from that side of things we've always gotten along well and worked together I think
outside of that you know we always get to know each other better and better with more time so
yeah I feel like we get along well and when you look at his data where is he particularly strong?
Good question I mean it's it's not just one specific area or specific thing
you know I think just I would say the biggest thing is that he's always there and you know even
if there are mistakes he's very good at minimizing the amount of time you lose from that I would say so
yeah it there's not one particular thing that you know I clearly go his mega here or bad here it's
you know chops and changes each weekend kind of thing but yeah he's obviously very quick and
your team boss Andrea Stella when he came on the podcast I I felt like I was being given a lesson
yes how to go motor racing because he just was so articulate the passion was obvious but also I found
myself just agreeing with everything he was saying so that makes sense that makes sense does that
help you definitely definitely yeah I mean I think Andre has been incredible for the team
not just for me but for everyone and McLaren like all a thousand people literally so
he's been great I mean you touch on his articulate language for a second language and
sometimes he says stuff that I kind of go do I even remember what that word means so it's very
impressive I mean he's very impressive in general and I think you know the culture that he's built
in the team the how's it going to interrupt but how would you describe that culture at McLaren?
I mean first and foremost performance driven you know I think there's no stone left unturned
you know we we all try to get performance from from everywhere and Andre is very much a driver of
that but I mean just in every every way you know from a motivation standpoint it's it's pretty
incredible the leadership is able to show and and sometimes even just keeping it simple you know
just having clear goals with what we want to do not over complicating things and staying sort of
true to the goal that's the one of the biggest things so I mean I could we could do like a whole
series on on Andrea but he's very very impressive and yeah I'm very happy that he's leading our team
you talk about goals let's talk about 2024 now um what are they what are the goals?
I think for me if I can keep working on the things that I want to improve from last year that
is the ultimately the biggest thing um you know I think trying to aim for podiums or wins or
points or whatever it might be is always it's not very productive I don't think I think if you've
got you know bar-range for example we didn't have a car that could win so if I had to set my
sights on trying to win the race I finished eight I'm only going to leave disappointed there so
whereas you know on the flip side I went into that raceboarding to work on how I managed the tyres
and you know be able to to look after them and you know not dig off massively and that I I feel
like I achieved pretty well so you know those two different perspectives for the same finishing
result completely changed the way you think about it so I left that race feeling very happy
and you know I think if I can keep doing those kind of things regardless of where we finish of
course if you get a trophy then the day it always makes you feel a bit better but I think knowing
that I've improved or done a good job that's by far the most important thing and then if as a
team we're in a position to to score a podium or hopefully eventually score a win then of course
you want to try and do that as well I feel Susuka might be the acid test for this car because
clearly you go incredibly well there in your first visit last year you know front row and everything
um do you feel that do you you're going to enter the Japanese Grand Prix going okay we're going
to find out where this car is relative to last year really I think Susuka again will be like
said a good test it's got a bit of everything the tarmac is quite unique almost in some ways a bit
like Bahrain or certainly it was last year a lot of high speed corners but again some very slow
corners which in the past haven't been our friend so if we can be quick around there I think that
would be a good test but yet to challenge Red Bull even on some of these different circuits I
think is still going to be very tough take Red Bull out of the equation it seems the field has
closed up yet again um you know in Bahrain you had Lewis Hamilton in front of you Fernando
Lanzo behind you two of the most experienced guys in Formula One do you do you relish racing
these people yes and no I mean when you're in the car no like there's another person you're trying
to beat really um but I mean yeah when you don't have the helmet on um yeah I mean it means a
little bit more when you're racing against someone like Fernando or Lewis um just because of the
history that they have and the success they've had in the sport so um it is pretty cool um definitely
but when you're on track honestly they're they're all the same in terms of wheel-to-wheel combat
are they doing different things to other people uh I mean I've crashed with Lewis a couple of times so
um I feel like both of them weren't particularly in my fault but um I don't know maybe it just
doesn't like me but I mean not not massively different you know you kind of know you know with
that that much experience you know that they're you know they're going to put the car in the
right place the strategy that they're going to you know work with their team um it is going to be
good um so you know from that side of things it's always going to be um you know you've got to be
on on your A game trying to beat them but I mean there's also kind of the mentality of you know you
can't treat them any differently um and you can't you know sort of have that uh that prejudice
because then you're going to raise some different you might raise some a bit softy you might
raise a bit harder um both of which can be bad um so you kind of just have to treat them as
as somebody else um and I think now that I've been in F1 for a year it's much easier to do that
certainly I think um Saudi here last year I think I lined up alongside Lewis on the grid um
and I remember someone showed me the start graphic after the race and I was like then that's
I mean my second F1 race alongside Lewis Hamilton like last year I was watching him line up on
the grid and now I'm sitting alongside my best best pre-dem co and when you do have an incident
let's call it that with someone like Lewis do you do you talk about it afterwards or
yeah I just want to know how you guys roll yeah no he's I mean yeah the the couple of times the
Lewis and I have had instances been um very good I mean the the one in in Monza he came up to me
straight away and um and shook my hands and said sorry um which you know you don't get from
everyone on the grid um the one in in Vegas was a bit of a 50-50 but we um you know spoke about it
in yeah we certainly weren't angry or pissed off at each other we just sort of spoke about it
and you know what we were trying to do and and why it went wrong and stuff so um yeah from that's
I think there's been yeah cool to cool to talk to and um yeah you certainly don't get that kind of
respect or discussion with with other people and when you think that they've done more than 300
for all pre um that's a level of respect as well isn't it exactly yeah I mean um
um can you imagine yourself doing that to to a rookie yeah I don't know but I actually had
um I think it was Mark actually said to me after Monza um you know if he if he didn't think much
of you wouldn't have me wouldn't have come and said anything um which I'm gonna trust Mark on that
one I feel like uh I see a good bit of advice or wisdom but um yeah that's a long time and you know
Lewis has not had that many incidents in his life so um you know it could be easy for him to
just to brush it off but I I had a lot of respect you know of course I wish that we didn't crash
in the first place but um no I had a lot of respect for you know being like that you mentioned
Mark Mark Weber of course uh your manager that's one example of how he's helped you I guess but
give us some other examples of how useful it is to have him as your your wingman and the kind
of advice he can give you whoo where to start um I mean it's it's so many areas um I mean the
first one is just the behind the scenes stuff um you know all the all the paperwork um
sorting out schedules um just making my life as simple as possible but anyone could do that for
you right anyone could do that but Mark has lived it through my shoes before um so you know he
knows that if I'm spending an extra half an hour here an hour here or whatever it might be he
knows the effect that that's going to have um on the weekend um you know if I have to go into the
weekend with distractions from something else and whatever's going on he knows the impact that
that's going to have because he's been there himself um so having somebody that's that's done that
you know being a driver themselves had a long career had a successful career that in so many
areas is is incredibly helpful um so that's sort of things is very important just the I mean even
from a team point of view you know who's been in a championship winning team in F1 in Weck um you
know in sports cars before that um so even just kind of the mindset and mentality brings
from that side of things is very insightful and very useful um and you know even still now he comes
up with questions for me that I haven't even thought about sometimes so um he definitely is you
know just as sharp as ever and um from a driving point of things is you know on a um trying to
trying to help me or you know in some cases um you know point out where I'm going wrong or whether
I can do something different or better um so it's just so many areas that he's um you know invaluable for
